TextEquiv.Unicode: evidently declared in the verie Creede
by that which followeth: For the next
is: He sitteth at the right hand of God
the father almightie.
For by this we understande what
kind of place Heaven is, and what our
Lord doth in heaven.
It is not surely for our frailtie o
ver narrowly to seeke out or discusse
the secretes of heaven, and yet it is
not against Religion to enquire after
that that is taught us in the Scrip
tures, and so perfectly to rememder
it as it is taught us. Our Lord is
simplie saide to sit, and that too, to
sit at the right hande of the father al
mightie.
Let us therefore see what the right
hand of the father is, and what it is
to sitte at the right hande of the Fa
ther
The right hande of the father in
the Scripture hath two significati
ons. First the right hand of God is
the place appointed for them that are
saved, and the everlasting felicitie in
heaven.
This did S. Augustine set down to
be marked long before us, who in the
twentie and sirt chapter of his booke
De Agone Cbristiano writeth, That
the right hand of the father, is the
everlasting felicitie given to the
Saintes : even as also the left hande
is most rightlie called the continuall
miserie allotted to the ungodlie: not
so that by this meanes that I have
saide the right or lefte hande is to be
understoode in respect of GOD him
elfe, but in respect of his creatures
capacitie. And this did saint Augu
stine speake according to the Scrip
tures. For David sayth: The path
of life shalt thou make knowne
to me the fulnesse of ioyes is in thy

evidently declared in the verie Creede by that which followeth: For the next is: He sitteth at the right hand of God the father almightie. For by this we understande what kind of place Heaven is, and what our Lord doth in heaven. It is not surely for our frailtie o ver narrowly to seeke out or discusse the secretes of heaven, and yet it is not against Religion to enquire after that that is taught us in the Scrip tures, and so perfectly to rememder it as it is taught us. Our Lord is simplie saide to sit, and that too, to sit at the right hande of the father al mightie. Let us therefore see what the right hand of the father is, and what it is to sitte at the right hande of the Fa ther The right hande of the father in the Scripture hath two significati ons. First the right hand of God is the place appointed for them that are saved, and the everlasting felicitie in heaven. This did S. Augustine set down to be marked long before us, who in the twentie and sirt chapter of his booke De Agone Cbristiano writeth, That the right hand of the father, is the everlasting felicitie given to the Saintes : even as also the left hande is most rightlie called the continuall miserie allotted to the ungodlie: not so that by this meanes that I have saide the right or lefte hande is to be understoode in respect of GOD him elfe, but in respect of his creatures capacitie. And this did saint Augu stine speake according to the Scrip tures. For David sayth: The path of life shalt thou make knowne to me the fulnesse of ioyes is in thy
peace and quietnesse,
And althought God in deede be not
shut up in any place. For hee saithr
Heaven is my seate, and the Earth the
footestoole of my feete: Pet because
the glorie of God doth most of all shine
in the Heavens, and because that in
heaven he giveth himelfe to be seene
and enioyed of them that are his, ac
cording to that saying: we shall
see him even as he is. And againe,
No man shall see me, saith the Lorde,
and live. Therefore God is saide to
dwell in Heaven,
Moreover Christ our Lorde tou
cthing his divinitie, is not shnt uppe
in any place, but according to his hu
manitie once taken, which he drew by
into heaven, hee is in the verie locall
place of heaven, neither is he in the
meane time here in earth and everie
where bodilie, but being severed from
us in bodie, remaineth in heaven. For
hee ascendeth, which leauing that
which is belowe, doth goe to that a
bove.
Christ therefore leaving the earth,
hath placed a seate for his bodie above
all Heavens. Not that hee is carried
up beyond all Heavens, but because
ascending up above all the circles into
the utmose and highest Heaven, hee
is taken (I say) into the place appoin
ted for those that are saved. For Paul
the Apostle speaking plainely ynough
to be understoode, saith: Our conver
sation is in Neaven, from whence
we looke for the Savrour to come,
Ecc.
In the same manner also Luke the
Evangelist saith: And blessing them,
he departed from them, and was caried
into Heaven.
But whie doe I make so much adoe
about expounding that which is most

peace and quietnesse, And althought God in deede be not shut up in any place. For hee saithr Heaven is my seate, and the Earth the footestoole of my feete: Pet because the glorie of God doth most of all shine in the Heavens, and because that in heaven he giveth himelfe to be seene and enioyed of them that are his, ac cording to that saying: we shall see him even as he is. And againe, No man shall see me, saith the Lorde, and live. Therefore God is saide to dwell in Heaven, Moreover Christ our Lorde tou cthing his divinitie, is not shnt uppe in any place, but according to his hu manitie once taken, which he drew by into heaven, hee is in the verie locall place of heaven, neither is he in the meane time here in earth and everie where bodilie, but being severed from us in bodie, remaineth in heaven. For hee ascendeth, which leauing that which is belowe, doth goe to that a bove. Christ therefore leaving the earth, hath placed a seate for his bodie above all Heavens. Not that hee is carried up beyond all Heavens, but because ascending up above all the circles into the utmose and highest Heaven, hee is taken (I say) into the place appoin ted for those that are saved.
